preloaded/ententen21_tt31:
general context - Corpus language: English. - Tokenization/annotation: each token has word form, lemma, POS tag, lempos, and lowercased variants. - POS tags follow a Penn Treebank–type tagset, grouped by regex patterns listed below; the tag format is fixed and strict (you must use these tags, not invented labels like ADJ, VERB, etc.). - Word sketches are available with many grammatical relations (listed below); they are not written directly in CQL but rely on the lemma/lempos and POS tags. how CQL should be written - Basic token query by word form: [word="cat"] (case‑sensitive). - Case‑insensitive word via lowercased form: [lc="cat"] (matches “cat”, “Cat”, “CAT”, etc.). - Query by lemma: [lemma="run"] (case‑sensitive). - Case‑insensitive lemma: [lemma_lc="run"]. - Query by POS tag: [tag="NN"] or by regex class [tag="N.*"] (standard Sketch Engine CQL; the tag string must follow the strict tagset format). - Query by alternative POS attribute: [pos="NN"] or [pos="N.*"] if needed (same tagset and format as tag). - Query by lempos: [lempos="run-v"] (lemma plus suffix; format is strict: lemma + hyphen + one‑letter POS code from the lempos list; no spaces, no other characters). - Case‑insensitive lempos: [lempos_lc="run-v"]. - Use structures in usual CQL way, e.g. within sentences: []{0,5} "example" , or filtering by document attributes with within/doc or subcorpora filters (e.g. within ). - Regular expression syntax is standard Sketch Engine/Manatee, e.g. [word="run(s|ning)?"]. - Remember that tag and lempos patterns are strict: you must use the exact tag strings (e.g. "NN", "VBZ") and lempos suffixes ("-n", "-v", etc.) as defined; other labels will not match. POS annotations (tag patterns – each line explains one pattern) - J.* – all adjectives (JJ, JJR, JJS etc.); used to annotate adjectives. - RB.? – all adverbs (RB, RBR, RBS, RB? etc.); used to annotate adverbs. - CC – coordinating conjunctions; used to annotate conjunctions. - DT – determiners; used to annotate determiners. - N.* – all nouns (NN, NNS, NNP, NNPS etc.); used to annotate nouns. - CD – cardinal numbers; used to annotate numerals. - RP – particles (e.g. up, out when tagged as particles); used to annotate particles. - IN – prepositions/subordinating conjunctions (in this corpus used as “preposition” class). - PP.? – personal and related pronouns (PRP, PRP? etc.); used to annotate pronouns. - V.* – all verbs (VB, VBD, VBG, VBN, VBP, VBZ etc.); used to annotate verbs. lempos suffixes - Lempos format is strict: lemma + "-" + one‑letter POS code (no spaces, always lowercase suffix). - -j – adjective lempos, e.g. big-j, important-j. - -a – adverb lempos, e.g. quickly-a, very-a. - -c – conjunction lempos, e.g. and-c, or-c. - -n – noun lempos, e.g. cat-n, information-n. - -m – numeral lempos, e.g. three-m, 10-m. - -i – preposition lempos, e.g. in-i, on-i. - -d – pronoun lempos, e.g. he-d, they-d. - -v – verb lempos, e.g. run-v, be-v, take-v. - Use these in CQL with lempos or lempos_lc, e.g. [lempos="take-v"], [lempos_lc="city-n"]. attributes and structures Token‑level attributes (use them as [attribute="value"] in CQL) - word – the original word/token form (case‑sensitive surface form). - tag – the POS tag (Penn Treebank–style; uses the strict patterns above). - pos – duplicate/parallel POS attribute using same tagset and format as tag. - lemma – the lemma in its original casing. - lempos – lemma + POS suffix (strict format: lemma + "-" + one‑letter code). - lempos_lc – lowercase lempos (lemma lowercased, same POS suffix). - lemma_lc – lowercase lemma. - lc – lowercase word form. Structural elements (used in CQL with and ) - g – structure "g" (generic grouping; exact linguistic role not specified). - s – sentence structure; use ... to restrict queries to sentences. - p – paragraph structure; use

...

. - p@heading – attribute "heading": indicates paragraph heading (e.g. p with a heading/title). - doc – document structure; top‑level container. - doc@url – full document URL. - doc@title – document title. - doc@wiki_categories – Wikipedia categories associated with the document. - doc@urldomain – web domain including subdomains (e.g. news.blogs.cnn.com). - doc@website – main website/domain (e.g. cnn.com). - doc@crawl_date – crawl date (full date/time as provided). - doc@modified_date – last modified date. - doc@tld – top‑level domain (e.g. com, org). - doc@wiki_translations – Wikipedia translations available for the page. - doc@modified_month – month of modification (numeric or string as stored). - doc@modified_year – year of modification. - doc@topic – topical category/label. - doc@tld_expl – interpreted/normalized TLD for English‑speaking countries (e.g. uk). - doc@domain_distance – distance from seed domains (numerical topical/domain measure). - doc@genre – genre label (e.g. news, blog). - doc@src – source label (data origin). - doc@crawl_year – year of crawl. grammatical relations (word sketch relations) These are predefined word sketch relations; you select them in word sketch functions (they are not normally typed directly in CQL, but you may need to know how they conceptually relate to lemmas/POS): - "%w" and/or ... – coordination of target with “and/or”. - "%w" is a ... – copular complement patterns with “is a …”. - %w's ... – possessive constructions where %w is the possessor. - -ing objects of "%w" – gerund (-ing) clause objects governed by %w. - ... is a "%w" – copular predicate where %w is the predicate noun/adjective. - adjective predicates of "%w" – adjectives used as predicate of %w (e.g. “X is happy”). - adjectives after "%w" – adjectives following %w (often in fixed patterns). - adjectives modified by "%w" – adjectives that take %w as their modifier. - adverbs modified by "%w" – adverbs that take %w as their modifier. - as reflexive – reflexive uses of pronouns with %w. - complements of "%w" – clausal or phrasal complements governed by %w. - in passive – passive constructions involving %w. - infinitive objects of "%w" – infinitival complements governed by %w (e.g. “try to go”). - it's "%w" to ... – patterns of “it is %w to …”. - modifiers of "%w" – words modifying %w (pre‑modifiers/post‑modifiers). - nouns modified by "%w" – nouns for which %w is a modifier. - objects of "%w across" – objects of phrasal verb %w + across. - objects of "%w along" – objects of phrasal verb %w + along. - objects of "%w apart" – objects of phrasal verb %w + apart. - objects of "%w around" – objects of phrasal verb %w + around. - objects of "%w aside" – objects of phrasal verb %w + aside. - objects of "%w away" – objects of phrasal verb %w + away. - objects of "%w down" – objects of phrasal verb %w + down. - objects of "%w in" – objects of phrasal verb %w + in. - objects of "%w off" – objects of phrasal verb %w + off. - objects of "%w on" – objects of phrasal verb %w + on. - objects of "%w open" – objects of phrasal verb %w + open. - objects of "%w out" – objects of phrasal verb %w + out. - objects of "%w over" – objects of phrasal verb %w + over. - objects of "%w through" – objects of phrasal verb %w + through. - objects of "%w unto" – objects of phrasal verb %w + unto. - objects of "%w up" – objects of phrasal verb %w + up. - objects of "%w upon" – objects of phrasal verb %w + upon. - objects of "%w whole" – objects of phrasal verb %w + whole. - objects of "%w" – direct objects governed by %w. - particles after "%w" – particles following %w in phrasal verbs. - particles after "%w" with object – particles following %w when %w also has an object. - possessors of "%w" – possessive dependents whose possessed noun is %w. - prepositional phrases – prepositional phrase relations associated with %w. - pronominal objects of "%w" – pronoun objects governed by %w. - pronominal possessors of "%w" – pronoun possessors of %w (e.g. “his %w”). - pronominal subjects of "%w" – pronoun subjects of %w. - subjects of "%w" – subjects governed by %w. - subjects of "be %w" – subjects when %w follows “be” (predicate complements). - verbs before "%w" – verbs that precede %w. - verbs complemented by "%w" – verbs taking %w as a complement. - verbs modified by "%w" – verbs that %w modifies (adverbial/adjectival). - verbs with "%w" as object – verbs taking %w as their object. - verbs with "%w" as subject – verbs taking %w as their subject. - verbs with particle "across" and "%w" as object – verbs + “across” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "along" and "%w" as object – verbs + “along” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "apart" and "%w" as object – verbs + “apart” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "around" and "%w" as object – verbs + “around” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "aside" and "%w" as object – verbs + “aside” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "away" and "%w" as object – verbs + “away” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "down" and "%w" as object – verbs + “down” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "in" and "%w" as object – verbs + “in” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "off" and "%w" as object – verbs + “off” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "on" and "%w" as object – verbs + “on” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "open" and "%w" as object – verbs + “open” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "out" and "%w" as object – verbs + “out” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "over" and "%w" as object – verbs + “over” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "through" and "%w" as object – verbs + “through” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "unto" and "%w" as object – verbs + “unto” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "up" and "%w" as object – verbs + “up” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "upon" and "%w" as object – verbs + “upon” where %w is object. - verbs with particle "whole" and "%w" as object – verbs + “whole” where %w is object. - wh-words following "%w" – wh‑words (who, what, where, etc.) that follow %w.
preloaded/europarl7_en:
general context - Corpus language: English. - Token-level positional attributes: word, tag, lempos, lemma, lemma_lc, lc. - Corpus is structurally annotated with sentence, paragraph, speaker, chapter, and document boundaries and IDs. how CQL should be written - Basic token query format: [attr="value"] where attr is one of: word, tag, lempos, lemma, lemma_lc, lc. - Use double quotes around attribute values; CQL is case-sensitive and all attribute names/values must match exactly. - POS tags are stored in the attribute tag; they are strict and must follow the given patterns (Penn-style), e.g. [tag="NN"], [tag="VBZ"], or regex like [tag="N.*"]. - Lemmas are stored in lemma (original case) and lemma_lc (lowercase), and the lowercase running form in lc; use [lemma="go"], [lemma_lc="go"], [lc="go"] as needed. - Lempos combines lemma + POS suffix with a hyphen, e.g. [lempos="go-v"], [lempos="water-n"]; the suffixes are fixed and must exactly match the table below. - Use regular expressions on attributes with ~ or by including regex meta-characters inside the quotes depending on system configuration, e.g. [tag="N.*"] for any noun tag. - Structural queries: use within / containing / intersecting clauses with structural names: - within … or within s for sentence-bounded searches. - within

…

or within p for paragraph-bounded. - within speaker, chapter, document similarly. - Structural attributes can be filtered, e.g. within speaker[name="John"] or within document[id="DOC123"] if your interface allows structure-attribute conditions. POS tag patterns (for attribute tag; each line = one mapping) - J.* = adjective (all POS tags starting with J, e.g. JJ, JJR, JJS are adjectives). - RB.? = adverb (RB, RBR, RBS are adverbs; the optional final character accounts for these variants). - CC = conjunction (coordinating conjunction). - DT = determiner. - N.* = noun (all POS tags starting with N, e.g. NN, NNS, NNP, NNPS are nouns). - CD = numeral (cardinal number). - RP = particle (verbal particle). - IN = preposition (and subordinating conjunctions tagged IN). - PP.? = pronoun (personal/possessive, including variants starting with PP). - V.* = verb (all POS tags starting with V, e.g. VB, VBD, VBG, VBN, VBP, VBZ are verbs). lempos suffixes - -j = adjective lempos suffix (e.g. happy-j). - -a = adverb lempos suffix (e.g. quickly-a). - -c = conjunction lempos suffix (e.g. and-c). - -n = noun lempos suffix (e.g. book-n). - -i = preposition lempos suffix (e.g. in-i). - -p = pronoun lempos suffix (e.g. he-p). - -v = verb lempos suffix (e.g. run-v). - Format of lempos is strict: lemma (exact lemma string) + hyphen + one of the above single-letter suffixes, no spaces or extra characters. attributes and structures Token-level positional attributes: - word = original word form (surface token). - tag = POS tag of the token (Penn-style, see patterns above; use exactly these values/patterns in CQL). - lempos = lemma + POS suffix (strict format: lemma-suffix). - lemma = lemma of the token (original case). - lemma_lc = lemma in lowercase. - lc = lowercased word form. Structural elements and their attributes: - g = generic grouping element "g". - s = sentence boundary. - s/@id = sentence identifier (id). - p = paragraph boundary. - p/@id = paragraph identifier (id). - speaker = speaker segment (for spoken/multi-speaker text). - speaker/@name = name of speaker. - speaker/@id = speaker identifier. - speaker/@language = language of speaker. - chapter = chapter boundary. - chapter/@id = chapter identifier. - document = document boundary. - document/@id = document identifier. - document/@wordcount= word count for the document. grammatical relations (word sketch relations) - adj_comp - adj_comp_of - adj_subject - adj_subject_of - and/or - infin_comp - ing_comp - it+ - modifier - modifies - np_adj_comp - np_adj_comp_of - object - object_of - part_across-x - part_across-x_obj - part_along-x - part_along-x_obj - part_apart-x - part_apart-x_obj - part_around-x - part_around-x_obj - part_aside-x - part_aside-x_obj - part_away-x - part_away-x_obj - part_down-x - part_down-x_obj - part_in-x - part_in-x_obj - part_intrans - part_off-x - part_off-x_obj - part_on-x - part_on-x_obj - part_open-x - part_open-x_obj - part_out-x - part_out-x_obj - part_over-x - part_over-x_obj - part_through-x - part_through-x_obj - part_trans - part_unto-x - part_unto-x_obj - part_up-x - part_up-x_obj - part_upon-x - part_upon-x_obj - part_whole-x - part_whole-x_obj - passive - possessed - possessor - pp_aboard-i - pp_about-i - pp_above-i - pp_across-i - pp_after-i - pp_against-i - pp_ago-i - pp_ahead-i - pp_albeit-i - pp_along-i - pp_alongside-i - pp_although-i - pp_amid-i - pp_amidst-i - pp_among-i - pp_amongst-i - preloaded/frtenten22_fl4:
general context
- Corpus language: French.
- Token-level annotation includes: surface form, POS tag, lemma, lemma+POS (lempos), several case-normalized and guess attributes, and morphological composites.
- Document-level metadata: URL, title, Wikipedia categories/translations, web domain info, dates, topic, genre, source, etc.

how CQL should be written
- Use standard Sketch Engine CQL.
- Token attributes (positional) are used as `[attribute="value"]`, e.g. `[tag="A.*"]`, `[lemma="faire"]`, `[lempos="aller-v"]`.
- Structural attributes (s-structures) are used with `within`, `containing`, and structural filters, e.g. `within <doc genre="news">`.
- POS tags are matched by regular expressions; the POS system is strict: each token’s tag must conform to exactly one of the given leading-letter patterns (A, R, C, D, I, N, Z, S, P, V).
- Tag format is strict:  
  - Full POS tags must start with the correct initial letter (A/R/C/D/I/N/Z/S/P/V) and then follow the tagset’s internal pattern (not detailed here).  
  - When writing CQL, use patterns like `"A.*"` for adjectives, `"N.*"` for nouns, etc.; assume that no tag violates this convention.

lempos suffixes
- Lempos = lemma + POS encoded as a suffix; use in CQL as `[lempos="lemma-suffix"]`.
- Suffixes are strictly fixed and must appear exactly as listed:
  - `-j`  = adjective lempos, e.g. `["beau-j"]`
  - `-r`  = adverb lempos
  - `-c`  = conjunction lempos
  - `-n`  = noun lempos
  - `-m`  = numeral lempos
  - `-i`  = preposition lempos
  - `-p`  = pronoun lempos
  - `-v`  = verb lempos
- Lowercase lempos is stored separately as `lempos_lc` with the same suffix system but lemma lowercased.

attributes and structures
Token-level attributes (each usable as `[attribute="..."]`):
- `word`        – surface word form as in the text.
- `tag`         – full morphological tag; POS is encoded in the first character (see below).
- `lempos`      – lemma + POS suffix (e.g. `aller-v`, `grand-j`).
- `gender_lemma`– lemma annotated/normalized with gender information.
- `tags`        – composed tag: a combined or multi-part morphological tag (e.g. multiword or composite morphology).
- `morphemes`   – segmentation of the token into morphemes (string representation).
- `gender_guess`– system’s guessed grammatical gender of the lemma/form.
- `number_guess`– system’s guessed grammatical number of the lemma/form.
- `lc`          – lowercased surface form.
- `lemma`       – base form / dictionary form.
- `lempos_lc`   – lowercased lemma + POS suffix.
- `lemma_lc`    – lowercased lemma only.
- `shorttag`    – shortened POS/morph tag (reduced version of `tag`).
- `pos`         – POS-only or simplified POS category (coarser than `tag`).

Structural elements (s-structures) and their attributes:
- `g` – structural unit `g` (generic; probably groups such as inline markup).
- `s` – sentence-level structure.
- `p` – paragraph-level structure.
  - `p@heading`     – paragraph heading information.
  - `p@lang_diff`   – language difference marker (e.g. language switch flag).
- `doc` – document-level structure.
  - `doc@url`              – full document URL.
  - `doc@title`            – document title.
  - `doc@wiki_categories`  – Wikipedia categories for the document.
  - `doc@urldomain`        – full web domain (e.g. `news.blogs.cnn.com`).
  - `doc@website`          – base website (e.g. `cnn.com`).
  - `doc@crawl_date`       – crawl date (full date string).
  - `doc@modified_date`    – last modified date (unreliable).
  - `doc@tld`              – top-level domain (e.g. `com`, `fr`).
  - `doc@wiki_translations`– links/ids for Wikipedia translations.
  - `doc@modified_month`   – month part of modified date (unreliable).
  - `doc@modified_year`    – year part of modified date (unreliable).
  - `doc@topic`            – assigned topic label.
  - `doc@domain_distance`  – distance from seed domains (numerical or categorical).
  - `doc@genre`            – genre classification.
  - `doc@crawl_year`       – year of web crawl.
  - `doc@src`              – source label.

POS tags (explain each part of tag on one line)
- Tag format (strict):  
  - First character = main POS; must be exactly one of: A, R, C, D, I, N, Z, S, P, V.  
  - Remaining characters = additional morphological features (case, gender, number, tense, etc.) whose internal code is not specified here but always follow immediately after the POS letter without separators.
- Mapping from first character to POS class (usable in CQL as `[tag="X.*"]`):
  - `A.*` – adjective (all adjective forms).
  - `R.*` – adverb.
  - `C.*` – conjunction.
  - `D.*` – determiner.
  - `I.*` – interjection.
  - `N.*` – noun.
  - `Z.*` – numeral.
  - `S.*` – preposition.
  - `P.*` – pronoun.
  - `V.*` – verb.

grammatical relations (word sketch relations)
These relations define how word sketches are computed; they also indicate dependency-like patterns you may want to replicate in CQL (e.g. co-occurrence patterns). All of them use `%w` as the node word (often lemma or lempos):

- `"%w" and/or ...` – coordinations where the node is conjoined with another element via “et/ou” or similar.
- `"%w" is a ...` – copular pattern where the node is subject complement (e.g. `X est un Y`).
- `... is a "%w"` – reversed copular pattern where `%w` is the predicate nominal.
- `adjective predicates of "%w"` – adjectives functioning as predicates with `%w` (often via “être” etc.).
- `adjectives after "%w"` – attributive adjectives following the noun `%w` (e.g. `livre intéressant`).
- `adjectives modified by "%w"` – adjectives whose modifier is `%w` (e.g. `vraiment intéressant` with `%w = vraiment`).
- `aller "%w"` – constructions with the verb `aller` and `%w` (e.g. infinitive or other complement).
- `devoir "%w"` – constructions with `devoir` and `%w`.
- `infinitive objects of "%w"` – infinitival complements functioning as objects of `%w`.
- `less "%w" than ...` – comparative patterns of the type “moins %w que ...”.
- `modifiers of "%w"` – all modifiers (adjectival, adverbial, etc.) modifying `%w`.
- `more` – comparative patterns “plus ...” relevant to `%w` (e.g. “plus grand que”).
- `noun modifiers of "%w"` – nominal modifiers governed by `%w` (e.g. `usine de voitures` with `%w = usine`).
- `nouns modified by "%w"` – nouns that are modified by `%w`.
- `nouns modified by noun "%w"` – nouns that are modified specifically by a noun `%w`.
- `objects of "%w"` – direct objects governed by `%w`.
- `pouvoir "%w"` – constructions with `pouvoir` and `%w`.
- `prepositional phrases` – prepositional phrase patterns related to `%w` (either governed or modifying).
- `prepositions preceeding noun/nouns after preposition` – link between prepositions and following nouns (PP heads/complements).
- `pronominal objects of "%w"` – object pronouns governed by `%w`.
- `pronominal possessors of "%w"` – possessive pronouns that take `%w` as possessed noun.
- `pronominal subjects of "%w"` – subject pronouns of `%w`.
- `pronoun is "%w"` – copular patterns where the complement is a pronoun `%w`.
- `subjects of "%w"` – subjects governed by `%w`.
- `subjects of "être %w"` – subjects of constructions where main verb is `être` plus predicate `%w`.
- `venir de "%w"` – constructions with `venir de` and `%w` (often recent past periphrasis).
- `verbs before "%w"` – verbs preceding `%w` (likely verbs taking `%w` as complement or in collocation).
- `verbs modified by "%w"` – verbs for which `%w` acts as a modifier (e.g. adverbial modifier).
- `verbs with "%w" as object` – verbs that take `%w` as direct object.
- `verbs with "%w" as subject` – verbs that take `%w` as subject.
- `with_definite_article` – occurrences of `%w` with a definite article.
- `with_indefinite_article` – occurrences of `%w` with an indefinite article.
- `être en train de "%w"` – progressive constructions with `être en train de` followed by `%w`.
